div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,145] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, MARCH 11, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels.
div.p: Catarnot Hotel, Assouan.

Thos most popular hotel on the Upper Nile has recently been enlarged by the additoon of 65 rooms and accomodates 360 gruests. Grand dining hall, lift, tennis courts and garden. On the south side overlooking the river. Billiard room and bar., Electric light throughout. Anglican Church within a few minutes of the Hotel grounds.

Grand Hotel Assouan. - Under the same management. Beautifully situated on river. Accomodates 50 guests. Moderate terms. Entirely rebuilt since the fire, and fitted throughout in the most modern style. Beautiful Terrance overlooking river. Electric light throughout.

div.head: The Railway Report
div.p: e are pleased to learn that the recommendations of the Railway Commission are beginning to take effect. We were able recently to announce that Major Johnstone, the present chairman of the administration, is to be the first general manager. He has oar good wishes in the task before him, and 'in its performance his high qualifications and past experience should stand him in good stead. We have, from the first, recognised the risks surrounding this appointment, and we are glad the Government has decided to accept the least of these. Major Johnstone's appointment must be accepted as emphasising the conclusion that the past defects in management were due to the system and not to the individual. We do not know what further proofs of the same may' be given, but it naturally occurs to ns that there will be vacancies upstairs for either or both of the other members of the present board of administration. Their great abilities and gear&l qualifications eminently fit them for such posts, but in ordinary business and on railways, we have seen a manager practically deprived of his proper position by predecessors in his office being similarly promoted. It must be clearly recognized that the work to be done is that of the general manager—he must not hark it if he will,— others must not do it if they can. Former partners in the job mast, if necessary, abandon their policy, and no longer continue in close touch with the work or the staff, or the whole change becomes a farce. The present army of secretaries must be rather a difficulty. Personality rather than utility often governs these very necessary or absolutely superfluous positions. The requirements I of the feature are a business secretary and . a private secretary to the general manager, and one to attend to the important and continuous duties of the official meeting*. The first of these is not to be found in Egypt nor easy to find anywhere. If he is not good enough to "dry nurse" or to carry on in a temporary emergency, some one else is wanted between him and the general manager. The commissioners have said that six-wheeled coaches rid$

rough. Verb. tap. The fact has to be boldly fired that the shears have to be applied not only to individuals, but to bodies of them, * h. accumulations of time, ^and job*, and the r««t We trust that it is decided to treat all, ant deserving cases in particular, with liberality We hope to see present incumbent* used ups far as is compatible with the object in visa but beyond these limits feelings must not gc Efficiency is to be the sole object and it must be secured from the tea^, and not attempts! rom the heart. In this view we symposia with Major Johnstone in his new position wit] bis old staff, but no one will more readily se he duty before him, .and the danger of delta in hesitations. He require* the support of all He has earned it, and the task is not of his own making.

One word as to the cost of all this. .It must involve a big sum of money as compensation The whole of it can be made and saved in year's working of the railways. If we are correctly informed, the Audit and Account department has been undertaken in the wriggle spirit Major Johnstone's bands have here ui doubtedly been strengthened by the recommendation of a gentleman outside the regular staff who is known* to possess the necessary experience, but this part of the deed has been doming very thoroughly and justly done, without fear, favor, or affection. May we be able to say I much, in due course, for the rest of the world The railways are undoubtedly to have, we wish we could say have got, — m audit not to be ignored, and the audit should now come forward and justify its exist each by taking its share in the responsibility for what is done or left undone in other depart meats. On the head of this department devolve no light nor pleasant duty. May he, too, have • he necessary courage to perform it. it is a open secret that the engineering department i to have a new chief. Under the circumstances it is well. He has to do or undo great and d»fi cult things. Evidently one of the first is t gather his work together, then he must reduce and reorganise his staff, and after this to "pressing needs" of the railways tau be attended to. The Commission have clearly laid dow the duties of the chief civil engineer of a railway, they have pointed to the excessive st perior staff, the changes needed are bat to clear. We are decidedly of opinion that there deputies (each with an assistant), of whom on would be in the head office, and perhaps "bridge adviser," is all the permanent stay necessary. The pay and responsibilities ma well be large, compared with those which ex is correspondence be reduced, and increased tin and attention given to work." With a lot new work some special assistance may be required for a time, and evidently an expert i required to demarcate land, eta, bat the su plus establishment will be large and mix01 The locomotive department is left in the on sent hands. It has escaped criticism by the Commission, but this may not mean this there is no room for internal reform. The on sent is the opportunity for it, and whether i be taken up voluntarily or under pressure, it i not to be lost We should be disappointed t learn that any persuasion is needed.

Evidently the new arrangements are base upon undivided responsibility, and beads < departments must feel it, and are evidently t be paid accordingly. But above all things, i the future their Fork must be theirs, over they most have authority, with it they may not part, with other people's work they have no right to interfere excepting on the appointed occasions—the official meetings to which 11 will refer. May they realise their powers 1 well as their responsibilities, and so person their duties that the general manager may b as little worried from below as from above. V have left to the last the all important earning department of the railways. We have mad our recommendation as to this, and we adhere to it The able and distinguished, officers 1 the head of the traffic department have 1 realise that its proper conduct is a very sera thing to the country, is a big lesson to lean and not to be picked up on these isolate railways. Disregard of the fact means the penditnreof time and money in gaining e: perinea which can be bought readily an (at any price) cheaply in comparison. In the and all departments we have a right to expect that economy be combined with efficiency, an that proper arrangements be made for and continuous supervision. We have 1 above to the institution of official It is on these occasions that the chief office! meet to discuss important problems, and3 necessary, the acts of each other With the proviso that these meetings are kept in ban they are most useful means of deliberation,-otherwise they are waste of time.

div.head:
FALL OF MUKDEN
COMPLETE RUSSIAN DEFEAT
BBRIG GUNS CAPTURED
FUSHAN OCCUPIED
FIERCE FIGHTING

div.p: (Official). The Russians, defeated in every direction, began to retire on Wednesday. The I'^-nese are in close pursuit. (Havas.)
The Japanese occupied Mukden at 10 a.m. today. (Havas.
Geneml Kuropatkiii telegraphs that the retreat of all his armies commenced this morning. (Havas)
The Japanese occupied Pushan yesterday evening. They captured all the big guns and threaten cut the Kirin road. [Havas.)
Fufhan was occupied yesterday evening. The fighting continues oti the northern heights of Pushan. Many Russian guns, including practically all the heavy ordnance, have been captured.
Oyama reports that the enveloping movement which has been practised for some days past has completely succeeded. Very fierce lighting continues in the vicinity of Mukden.
A great number of prisoners, and enormous quantities of arms, ammunition, and supplies have, been taken. (Reuter.}

div.head: MR. C. NICOLAOITS CONCERT.
div.p: The distance that divides the stage from the concert-hail is a subject on which operatic artistes are apt to filler widely. While some assume a staid and reserved deportment before a concert audienc, others' endeavour in a certain measure to replace the platform by the "boarus,' and to this latter category belongs Mr. c. Nicolaou, whose concert last night at the New Kuedivial Hotel was very well at timed. We are lar from considering that a display ot Mr. Nieoiaou's histrionic was aecia when interpreting what, with a few exceptions,

" was an operatic programme ; but it must be borne in mind that, in a concert, such talent is of secondary importance and must not be allowed to serve as a blind to the rendering ol music jjtr >Y. Mr. Nicolaou is the possessor ol a tine poweilul voice,capable of tilling any opera house. He cannot theretore but have undergone some dilliculty in reducing it to the compass ol a comparatively small concert-room, and tbis caused us to teel that we were deprived ot appreciating bis accomplishments to their tull extent. Ills programme, as we have said, was largely operatic, and opened with a "Graud Air," Irom Verdi s ihn Carlost ib which he was satisfactory, hut if anyUiiug insuthciently melodious. His reudenug of FalstalFs "Air'lrumThomas's Midsummer Sight's Dream was vigorous though a trifle hard. The Drinking Bong from Bizet s Fair Jlaid of Perth showed Mr. Nicolaou to lar better advantage and was a spirited performance. Tbis was followed by thebeuuliful "Stances a JLakunT ol Delibes, in which he struck us a« somewhat unconvincing. Mr. Nicolaou was decidedly at his best in his interpretation of Handel's "War Bong" from the oratorio founded ou Dryden's "Alex andor's Feast." Here his commanding bau- tono luund tto lull scope, while his bass notes were truly excellent, and he may be said to have well lulhlled P. Gevaert's dicta*(inserted iu the progtamme) as to the vocal requirements for the production of this work. Mr. Nico- laou's manner of singing the "Ballata del Pischio" from Boito's Mejistofele was properly gruesome, while Mepbisiophelea'Bcreuade Irom Gounod's Faust was given with much eclat. Iu the ' Air'' from the Suets de Figaro of Mozart, he was less happy, but thoroughly captivated the bulk of his audience by stirring their national spirits with several Greek melodies.

Mr. Nicolaou was assisted in his concert by the violin solos of Mr. Afeudoulis, who was ably accompanuied by Mmo. Foscolo; be played with great ease aud correctness, if somewhat lacking in verve and sentiment. The "Airs Hougrois" ol Tinudelli were well given ; but of Tschaikowsky's ditficult "Canzonetta" he proved himself thoroughly master and quite carried aw*y his audience. In Neruda's "Berceuse Blave"a wanton sympathy was noticeable, but the performance left otherwise nothing to be desired. Mr. Felix's pianoforte contribution* were, though performed with dash, not entirely to "concert pitch,"
The White Star Liner "Cnpie" Leaves Alexandria this afteroon on the continuation of her cruise in the Mediterranean.

div.head: Alhambra.—
div.p: A cake walk competition will take place at the Alhambra this evening and to-morrow, when prizes will be given to the best dancers. Masked balls will be given after the usual performance on both evenings.

Train Outrage.—-Our Luxor Correspondent rcpoVts that as the "traiu de luxe" was passing through on Wednesday night irom Cairo, some unknown person fired at the engine-driver and injured him slightly .u the hand.

Salt and Soda Co.—The sales of salt goring February amounted to L.E. 20,512.404. In February, 1904, they were L.E. 22,752.186. The total sales since Jauua'y 1 amounted to LE. 43,714 102; last year they were L.E. 47,558.267.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: —11 vessels passed through the Canal on the 8th iust., 4 of which were British, 2 German, 1 Austrian, 1 French, 1 Norwegian, 1 Dutch, 1 Turkish. The receipts for the (lay were Irs. 289,179.68, making the total from the 1st, iust. Irs: 2,459,687.03.

, Cruise.—The Austrian Lloyd S.S. "Thalia" is due to arrive at Alexandria on Tuesday next with a nurnbei of Jewish pilgrims oq board, bound for the Holy Land. The vessel Will leave for Jaffa ou the 18th inst., after allowing the passengera to visit Cairo.

Celebration.—The celebration of the 25th anniversary of the foundation of the Austro- Hungarian Benevolent Society at Alexandria will take place on Monday next at the New Kbedivial Hotel A bauquet will take place in the evening at which all the members of the society will be preseut.

Coal Imports.—Prom the 1st January to 9th March the coal imported into Egypt amounted to 120,789 tous, as against 201,516 touareceived last year duriug the same period. Newcastle sent 23,500 tons, the Welsh districts 67,657, the Scotch districts 16,102, Yorkshire 7,806, and other places 5,724 tons.

Church Missionary Society.—An interesting ceremony will take place at the mission compound in Old Cairo on Friday, 17th iust, when Sir Algernon Coote, Bart, (vice-president of the parent society,' aud president of the C.M.S. in Ireland), will lay the foundation stone of the ' Ethel Pain Memorial Hospital." The Right Rev. Bishop Biyth will conduct the service.

Cairo Railway Station.—Electro pneumatic signalling lias been contracted fur at this station ; but it would, iu the opinion of the Railway Commission, be desirable to postpoue this work until a more definite aud comprehensive plan for the laying out ol the whole of the lines in Cairo station and sidiugs has been decided upon. No estimate or plan for this had been furnished to the Comiuis*iou, but with the primitive conditiou of the signalling in all other parts of Egypt, they think that this electro-pueumatic signalling can hardly be necessary.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: THe Moss liner "Menes" sailed yesterday afternoon from Liverpool and is due here about the 25th inst., with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The Moss liner "seti" arrived yesterday afternoon from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers, nd Malta, with passengers, ails, and general cargo.
The Moss Liner "Pharos" arrived here yesterday afternoon from Constantinople.
The messageries Maritimes S.S. "Congo" arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria on Wednesday afternoon.
The S.S. "Creole Prince." from Anterwep and Middlesbro' , left Malta on Friday and is due here on Tuesday next, with passengers and general cargo.
The Ellerman S. S. Sardina arrived at Liverpool on Thursday evening from Alexandria.
The Khedivial S.S. "Prince Abbas" will leave Alexandria on Wednesday fro Pineus, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.

div.head: P. & O. COMPANY.
div.p: We are desired to state that the P. & 0. Company's main line steamers to Marseilles regularly leave Port Said at 5 p.m. every Monday after the arrival of the 11 o'clock morning train from Cairo, and a steam tender awaits the train to convey passengers on board.

div.head: The Pilgrimage
ARRIVAL OF STEAMERS AT SUEZ
div.p: Suez, Friday.

The Khedivial Mail liner "Minieh" and the Russian steamer "Tsaritza" are the first pilgrim steamers to arrive here on their way home. The former, bound for Constantinople, has ou board 1,300 foreign pilgrim-*, while the latter carries 1,177 bound to Theodosia. The health' of the pilgrims is satisfactory, and both steamers entered the Canal in quarantine at 2 o'clock this afternoon.
The S.S. ""Odessa" left Jeddah to-day with 1,450 Russian pilgrims on board.

div.head: WIRELESS TELEGRAPHY AT SUEZ.
div.p: Suez, Friday.

Arrangements have now been concluded between Uoyd's and the Marconi International Marino Communication Company for the equipment of the Port Tewfik station with their system of wireless telegraphy, and the apparatus left London on the 3rd inst by the S.S. "Victoria," which i9 due to arrive at Suez on Wednesday night. The apparatus is in charge of an export from the Marcoui Company. The station is expected to be ready shortly, and will oomuiuQtcate with steamers in the Red Sea haviug wireless apparatus on board.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive attended Friday prayers at Montaz&h Mosque yesterday.
To-day, his Highness goes to Matrouh and will proceed on his excursion to the Libyan Desert, accompanied by his suite.

div.head: THE STRANDING OF.THE "CAIRO."
div.p: The ei quiry into the circumstances attending the stranding of the Florio-Rubattino S.S.

' Cairo" at i he entrance to Alexandria harbour has been concluded at the Italian Consulate. The report of the enquiry, which is being kept private, is to be sent .to-day by the Italian Consul-General to the Minister of Marine at Rome, who will in his turn forward it on to the Italian Admiralty.
Captain De Marchi will remain at Alexandria until he receives further instructions.
Efforts are being made to salvage as much os possible of the ship's cargo for the account of the insurance companies interested.
No attempt will be made to refloat the vessel until the salvage operations have been practicully completed. The position of the vessel is still much the same as on Monday morning.
The salvage steamer "Hermes" remains in the harbour, but is taking no part in the salvage operations.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
div.p: MUSSULMAN ART.

The Government of Algiers has formulated a project eminently worthy of Frehch instinct for art. It is to hold in Algiers a general exhibition of Mussulman art, African and Syrian, from the remote centuries of the early Caliphs down to the present day. Tho exhibition will synchronise with the assembling of the congresses of Orientals and inter-colonial societies at Algiers in April next. All tie Arab tribes and all the great African chieftains, Algerian, Moorish, and Tripolitan, have promised every assistance, and the classical periods of Persia, Syria, and the Hispano-Mauresque will be represented inevery branch of art work. In other words, every cen tury of Arab work, in all its handicrafts, will come under review at their best, and down to their present worst

div.head: Savoy Hotel, Luxor.
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its psition on the Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate charges. Patronized by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.

div.head: NOTES FROM FAYOUM
THE CASSEL FUND
div.p: (Prom ou» Correspondent).
Fayoum, March 9.
The Travelling Ophthalmic Hospital is doing good work here. Up to this date about five thousand patients have attended tho hospital, about two hundred of whom were operated on.

Dr. MacallaD, the English oculist, iuvited me to attend his operations, and 1 have seen him making different operations such as for tri- chioeis, artificial pupils, cataract, trochoma, and grafting operations, etc., with excellent results.
FAYOUM S.P.CJL

Only yesterday this society was organised here, the Moudir as president and Mr. Way, of the Agricultural Bank, as secretary; there are about thirty members, and it is expected others will join shortly. It is intended to build a hospital for animals.
Major Elgood helped in the foundation of the society here, and it is expected to be of muoh-jervioe in protecting the poor animals in this provicce.

div.head: FAYOUM ELECTRIC LIGHT.
div.p: The Nazleh waterfall could geuerate about nine hundred h.p. which might be used for various purposes,one of which would be to light the town ot Fayoum. A Swiss engineer is here preparing a scheme for a company which intends to carry out this work.

div.head: MOUDIR 0F SHARKIEH.
div.p: Mouheb Bey's many friends here very muoh regret that he is going to leave the Fayoum for his new post as Moudir of Sharkieh.

div.head: EGYPT'S DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: I agree with the writer of "Under the Mosquito Net," that this country is advancing in every way aud that everybody can see the difference between Egypt of thirty years ago and Egypt of to-day. The industrious peasant is quite safe now and is working his lands very successfully. But I would ssk him to write about backshish and drink, which are checking the development and prosperity of the country. The district employes are continually taking backshish from the peasants. Their chiefs of course know this, but cannot prove it, because the others take great precautions to cover their misdeeds.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
K. S. C. GYMKHANA.
div.p: A very successful Gymkhana was held at the K.8.G. ground at Gbezireh yesterday afternoon in fine weather, and before a large number of spectators, who greatly appreciated the sport provided. Among them were Major-General Slade, C.B., and Miss Slade, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer, Sir William Garstin, Mr.'M. de

Findlay, C.M.G., and Mrs. Findlay, the Hon. F. 0. Liudley, Mr. Rumbold, Mr. Higgins, Mr. Carter Wilson, CoL Friend Colee Pasha- and the Misses Coles, the Hon. A. Stanley, Mrs. Graham, Mrs. Dudgeon, Mr. and Mrs. Astley Friend, Mrs. Soott-Dalgleish, Capt and Mrs. Bay ley, Judge Royle, Mrs. and Mias Royle, Crookshank Pasha anil Mrs. Crookshank, Capt Gilleon, the Misses Hurley, Mrs. Marshal Hewat, Major and Mrs. Delavoye, Mr. and. Mrs. Purvis, and many others, including alLor nearly all the officers of the Army of Occupation and the Egyptian Army.

The events were interesting and in many cases extremely amusing, the hat-trimming and house-keeping competitions being perhaps the best. The Affinity Stakes were easily wou by Capt the Hon. A. Stanley and Miss Hurley from 10 other competitors, while the D&k Race Was a hollow victory for Mr. Langley. The hat-trimming competition was greatly enjoyed, the incogruity of the hats, —and very pretty many oj them were—held on by male riders going at full gallop being quite comic. The House-keeping Stakes revealed a sad absence of the higher ma^uematios among the ladies, who mostly succumbed to the fatal problem of the "herring and & half that cost 1} piastres," aud of whom oue only gave her companion a correct answer. The last event was very interesting, Capt and Mrs. Bay ley and the Hon. A. Stanley, with Mins Hurloy, giving a very good display of riding.
The following is the list of prize-winners :—
Bucket contest—Mr. Mellor.
Novice Stakes.—Capt Bayley's horse, ridden by Mr. Starkey.
Affinity Stakes.—Mr. Hemp and MissLaing.

DAk Race. —Mr. Langley.
Ladies' Sourry.—Mrs. Wood.
House-keeping Stakes.—Mr. Dalby and Miss Seymour.
Tilting the Ring.—Capt. and Mrs. Bayley.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOLF CHAMPIONSHIP.
div.p: After a most interesting competition, the final round was decided on Thursday last, Mr.

Morice winning from Mr. E. P. Blenoowe after a capital game. Both players were troubled throughout by the strong glare and the keenness of the ""greens." The game opened cautiously, play being unexoitiug for the first 2 holes. A fine iron shot out of a dusty lie enabled Morice to claim the lead at the 3rd hole. This he quickly iucreased, winning' the 5th and 6th by correct play, Bleocowe's tee shots running wild At the 7th both drove well over the rails, but Morice was all at sea in the short game and lost the hole comfortably. The 8ih was halved by untidy golf; Blencowe overran his pitch at the 9th aud Morice turned 3 up. He increased his lead to 4 up at the 10th, where he rattled iu a fine put for 3. A poor tee shot at the next hole found Morice in the sand, and Blencowe, making no mistake, reduced the lead to 3. Morice hit a big shot off the 12th tee and went ahead again, and after correct 4*s at the 13th, the match ended on the 14th green, where Morice found his iron shot within 6 ft. of the hole with "2 for the cup."
The following are the full results of the competition :—
1st round.
Capt MacMurdo beat Capt Bayley.
Mr. E. P. Blencowe beat Mr. Duncan Miller. Mr. A. Cameron beat Mr. Soott-Dalgleish. Mr. A. P. Friend *|Mr. Mackenzi

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Price Aziz Pasha Hassau has returned to Alexandria from Cairo.
Sir F. R Wingate Pasha, Governor General of the Sudan, is expected at Cairo on Monday from Suakin.
Our Luxor Correspondent states that the ex-Empress Engeuie has arrived there on her way back from Khartoum, and will stay at Luxor for a few days before returning to Casio.

An interesting story is told by "M.A.P." of the last visit of the Empress to Egypt:— When she last visited Cairo she was in the enjoy mentally that the world could give, beauty of a rare type, admired by ail, a happy wife, a proud mother, a throne which she gracefully' occupied. It was at Cairo that she heard of a celebrated Dervish, and determined to consult him. Thickly veiled and diqpieed, she went, accompanied by oue ol her ladies in attendance, to see him. On entering his abode the Dervish rose, made a low obeisance, and addressed her thus : "Weloome, you are thrice welcome' to my humble dwelling, oh, Effipress I* Eugenie, vexed and astonished, replied, "How do you know that I am an Empress, and who told you I was coming here V' The Dervish answered: "The stars and Mohamed know everything. I knew since your arrival in Egypt that you would come to ' me, and L have patiently waited every night, for afterwards I am commanded by Allah to make my last journey to Mecoa and die."

The Empress, very frightened, was getting up to leave, for she began to fear this mysterious man, but, summoning courage, she said, in a haughty tone: "It is true that I am * the Empress, though no one knows it but my attendant; tell me what you can'of my future, tell me all, and tell me truly," at the same time offering him her hand, and showing him the palm to examine ; but the old seer never touched her jewelled fingers. Raising himself to his full height, and dropping his staff, he held his hand aloft as in invocation to Allah. Looking down piteously on the dark figure of the Empress, he murmured slowly, "There is no God but God and Mohamed is His Prophet At yourbirth the stars foretold for you great powe and greater sorrow, for your happiness will only be temporary, but your sorrow will last for ever. You are doomed to lose your throne, your husband, and your son, and, wander alone through the world like a lost star." ,

""These events will not happen' at once, for the blow would kill you. To ypu as an Empress it will not be permitted to enter the Land of your husband or son, except by permission of those you despise. You will have to seek a home with strangers, and the dress of woe will never leave your form; your jewels will be but tear drops. I have said." He had scarcely ceased speaking when the Empress, terrified and angry, threw at his feet a purse of gold, crying out: "You base impostor, take the fruit and reward ot your liea and let me out of your den." Then, rushing hurriedly out, she ran swiftly away. This strange and unhappy prediction was made n 1869 ; how literally it has been fulfilled, events have proved.

Among the distinguished visitors who have been making a prolonged stay at the Anglo- American Company's Savoy Hotel on Elephantine Island are H.R.H. Prinoe George of Hanover, travelling incognito as Grat Diepholz; Earl Howe, who is Chamberlain to Queen Alexandra ; Countess Howe and her sister, Lady Sarah Wilson ; Sir Edward and Lady Colebrooke, the latter of whom is one of the handsome daughters of the late Lord Alfred Paget; the Hon. John Ward, brother of the Viceroy of Ireland ; Sir Ernest Cassel and his sister, Mrs. Cassel ; Mr. William Waldorf Astor ; Sir Augustus FitzGeorge, son of the late Duke of Cambridge ; Sir Gerald FitzGerald; Mr. MfcEwnn, M.P., and his daughter, Mrs. Ronald Greville, and the Hoo. Patrick and Mrs. Greville Nugent.
We are sorry to hear that H.E the Governor ot Alexandria is oonfined to his room with a slight indispoeition.
It is stated that Major Le Breton is likely to enter the service of the Delta Light Railway Company.

The following passengers left Cairo yesterday by the P.S. "Hatasoo" for the Nile trip.— Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Carter, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Kei), Mrs. Syme, Mrs. Fulmer, Mrs. W. W. and Miss Emily W. Shirk, Miss L. Maude Port, Mrs. Thos. W. Warner, Mrs. Chas. and Miss Ruth Battcher, Miss M. Florence Jaooby, Mr. M. E Sentelle, Miss M. A. Pattison, Dr. Saylor Brown, Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Randle, Mr. and Mrs. Geo. W. Maring, Mrs. Judith A. Gillam, Miss Elir. A. Maring, Rev. Dr, G. Wj and Mrs. Kemper, Mr. D. A. Syme, Mr. John Elderkin, Hon. A. L. Kcrwood, Prof. D. H. H. Shewmaker, Mr. N., Mr. B., Miss M. H. and Miss D. M. Benson, Mr. and Mrs. H. C. and Miss Kent, Mr. and Mrs. Haas Siebermann, Mr. and Mrs. Stiehl, Mr. F. div.head: TYROL.
div.p: Weissenstein Castle 3410 ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch-Matrai ' Station, Lienx (reached from Venice or Trieste). Bracing air. Good Mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing. best June, September. Apply Proprietor.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the west Central position. Under English management.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: The 3rd Battalion Rjtle Brigade, now af Aden, is expected to return to England early inthespringafter eighteen years' foreign service. It will be stationed at Portsmouth. No official intimation has been given of the date of the move of the 2ud Battalion from E^ypt t India.
Major H. E. Taylor, Royal Berks Regiment, on giving up the adjutancy of the 3rd Battu lion Welsh Regiment, has boon posted to tli 1st Battalion at Dublin.

' Lieutenant Hamilton Hodgson, Lincolnshire Regiment, w^o has served .with the* Egyptian Army for the past five and a-half years, has been promoted cipt&in in his own regimen*. He had to serve the very long subaltern service period of ten years for his third -star Captain ^odgson was with the 1st Lincolns in Kitchener's Sudan Campaign, 1898, and was prosent at Omdurman (tne lal, Khedive's me dal, with clft«p).
QuartenuAster Morris, Royal InniskiRing Fusilier, lately promoted from the ranks, has joined the 1st Battalion at Derry.

Tile 2nd Battalion the Buds at Salisbury Plain will go to Malta in the autumn ami after that to India. Curiously, this battalion, although it has been nearly half a century in existence, has never yet been in India, it-» previous foreign service having been spent in Malta, West Indies, Gibraltar, Natal (Zulu War 1879), Singapore, Hong Kong, Egypt (Frontier Campaign), and South Africa, in eluding the late Boer War, in which it greatly distinguished itself.
It is announced that no reduction will be made in the cavalry force in South Africa. It will consist of four regiments, exclusive of the 2nd, 5th, and 6th Regiments of Mounted Infantry.
H.M.S. "Edgar" has been selected as the flagship of Vice-Admiral D. H. Bosanquet, commanding the Particular Service Squadron, in relief of H.M.S. "Ariadne.'*

There is a whisper going round that the reduction of the Mediterranean Fleet has not met with entire approval at the Admiralty, where "Jacky Fisher" is laying down the law of the "blue water school for ever" in no uncertain manner. Perhaps this view will be emphasised by the deduction ot Captain Klado, who would have us believe that the Bluck Sea Fleet at an early period will be liberated to go to the Far East—the very Fajr-~East. Iu his just published book the hero of the phantom torpedo boats of the Dogger Bank says—"Is it possible that n Power struggling for its threatened life and having a singlo aru capable of striking a fatal blow at the euerny is obliged not to Use it T That would be revolting and^ inadmissible stupidity. We must triumph overdiplomatic obstacles." Quite so. Sueh unconsidered trilles as mutinous sailors.burningareoDals, and arevolted popula» e do not enter into the calculations of the erudite Klado.

div.head: The Sorrows of FUAD PASHA
HUMOURS OF PRISON LIFE IN SYTRIA
div.p: HUMOURS OF PRISON LIFE IN SYRIA.

The rumours that Marshal Fuad Pasha ha* 6sCaped from his prison house in Damascus where he has been incarcerated for three year for firing on the spies of tho Ottoman Govern moot, who dogged his every footstep, are unfounded. He is still under the hand of th* Sultan, and has lately suffered more rigorou persecution.

To Western minds, some of the incident Which have marked his imprisonment ar humorous in the extreme. The Marshal's set vant bears a striking resemblance to his distinguished master, and in this the wily guard who watch the house saw danger. The servan was in the habit of going daily to a restaurant to fetch the Marshal's dinner. On one of the* expeditions he was arrested and thrown intc* prison, and was only released when he ha agreed to shave off his beard. It was fearc that Fuad Pasha would one day take advn* tage of the servant's facial likeness and effec' his escape, so the precaution of removing tin hireling's hirsute adornment was resorted t*.

Shortly afterwards an almost equally ludi crous inciHen t occurred. Near the Marshal's hon some ceremonies in connection with the inau guratiouofarailwaywereproceeding, wbenFua' Pasha appeared on his balcony. The troop saluted him, for although he has been de prived of his decorations, he still has militan tank. The authorities at Yildiz, being i» formed by its spies of the respects, at one sent orders to Damascus to erect & high scree? of timber in front of tho Marshal's windows, ii order to prevent him from looking on tin street

The object of all this persecution lies in th Sultana fear that Marshal Fuad Pasha, wh< still remains popular, might put himself at tin command of the army in Syria, and march inland to attack him from Scutari.

div.head: CAIRO S.P.C.A
div.p: To the Editor of- the "Eoyptian Gazette."

Sir,— 1 think that you expect a little too much from our visitors. No doubt those in «ympathy with the objects of the society, and able to subscribe liberally to its funds, make heir contributions at home, and it is hardly to he expected that, in arranging their holiday •>ure, they will take into account subscriptions *» philanthropic objects, in providing the ne pessary funds for their trip to this country.

But there is a way in which they may be eached, and I am surprised that it is not mop- reely adopted by the committee of the society in Cairo. Our visitors are hero for pleasure. »nd will no doubt spend their money all tin* •iorc freely if to pleasure can bo added tin- ending thatin enjoying themselvestheyarehelp ng to do good. It is not too late even this sea on to get up one or two entertainments, the >p«fits of which should be given to the S.P.C.A iVould not the company, for instance, who «re riving such an excellent representation ot "The 'irates of Penzance" arrange another perform uce for fo excellent an object ? Probably, if pproached, they would willingly do so.

The letter of your correspondent "S.P.C.A. •f A." has just come under my notice, and I • m surprised to find on enquiry that there s no central committee of the S.P.C.A. actine or the whole of Egypt It seems to me that <uch a central body is absolutely necessary or the proper carrying out of such work as thi- n Egypt Branch committees in all impor tant centres by aU means, but how can the work be thoroughly and efficiently done with nit a central body who are able to provide for the enforcement of the law in every district throughout the country I I fail to see how i-oMted local action, dependent entirely upon mrely voluntary effort on the part of indivi Inals, can be made really efficient, or covei -he whole of the ground that requires atten ion, and most certainly tho advantages that he Cairo committee enjoy in facilities fot •Staining funds should be exercised for the ■enefit of the community at large.—Iam, etc.,

At'ihe annual meeting of the general committee of the Cairo S.P.C.A., held in March. 1904, it was decided that an official request in tho name of thecommittee should be addressed to the Ministry of the Interior, to the eftW that instructions should be issued to the mon- dire, forbidding tho fellaheen to use, when ploughing vifh horses or donkeys, yokes of tho kind employed for buffaloes.

The committee have sustained a serious loss in the death of Tigrane Pasha, who took a great interest in the work of the society. Ti grane Pasha was always present at the annual general meetings, and his advice and sympathy were of material assistance in furthering the objects of the society, of which he was such a prominent member.
(To be continued).
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Dear Sir,—After reading your article, in yesterday's "Gazette," on the S.P.C.A., it struck me it would be an excellent plan if boxes for collection were put in each hotel. At present there is simply an open list on notice-board at the hotels requesting donations from visitors, but without stating where such donations can be paid. As a largo number of visitors to this country have only a limited me for sight-seeing, naturally they h&vo no time to spare in making enquiries as to whom donations could be paid, and this, much to the detriment of tho S.P.C.A. fund. By having boxes, with a short uoticq, in promiuent posi tions asking for assistance for the society, 1 feel sure many visitors would be only too happy to drop in small sums for the fnnd, which at the end of season would produce a con. siderable amount for such a deserving society as the S.P.C.A. I would suggest the collecting box be made with opening large enough for letters, as iftany people might prefer enclosing cheque or paper money.—Youre faithfully,
P. Black.
Cairo, March 10.

div.head: SUDAN RUBBER
div.p: Amongst the product* of the Sudan which have been looked iorward to as likely to prove of the greatest commercial importance are "rubbers, the demand for which iu the Euro- -p°an market is always on the increase, and especially for those of superior qu-Uity. In Anglo-Egyptian Africa, '"as well as in British Africa, these are furnished, not as in Brazil, Central America, and certain puts of India,by Urge trees, but, as in Milaya, by creeping stout stemmed shrubs, with ornamental llowers and fruit, which mount to the summit of the highest trees, and belong to the natural order "Apocynacea*." There appear to be at least two or threev of these rubber-!umishing creepers in theSudan, and especially one known to the natives of the Bahr-el-Ghazal Province as "odiloh" (1), but of which the botanical name has not been promulgated ; this produces rubber of a very superior quality. The best of these plants belong to the genus "Lindolphia" ; but little progress has yet been made in the development of the ipdustry, owing to the absence of suitable machinery' for extracting the rubber, and to the dirty processes as yet in vogue for preparing it, which prevent its acceptance in the E6ropean market except at a very Jow rate.

We now learn that the Congo Administra tion has succeeded in bringing into the market a species of Landolphia as yet scientifically unnamed ; but which is known familiarly as "Grass rubber/' and has already brought a small fortune to the treasury of the King of the Belgians. From a paper recently read before the Liunean »Society by Mr. Thomas Christy, of the fanSous firm of T. Christy and Co., commercial druggists, London, it appears that this plant is a low growing one-which has the property of throwing ont long shoots, or roots, when only a few feet from the ground, ami it is those roots which furnish the rubber ; it is mostly found amongst grass which has sprung up in a forest clearing after a fire— hence its popular name. The roots contain a white fibrous mass which is, c unpamtively, dry and elastic, and replaces the ordinary milky sap.

By bruiring with a machine the skin of these roots, with great care so as not to break up the fibre, the latter is easily separated and rolled into boll* having the appearance of boiug male ^of thick tape The roots contain about 18 % of pure rubber fetching from 3s. 9d. to 4a. per lb. and immense quantities from the Congo h ivo already been .disposed of at these prices. This species of rubber plant is abundant in British Africa, and especially in Rhodesia, where it has hitherto beep ignorantly ueglected, but the trading companies, having become suddenly alive to its commercial importance, are now vying with one another in promoting its development Many hundreds of young plants grown from semi have been successfully started in Ceylon. Let us hope that the Sudan Government will lose no time in a search for tho "grais rubber," and iu obtaining its share in th^ immense profits now beiug realised with it by the Congo Government.*
A; H. S.

P.S.—Should the concentrationofthe rubber sap into fibre, in the shoots or roots of the Congo plant turn out to be due to the effect of the destructive and wasteful forest fires so frequent in tropical Africa, which thus develop a new habit in life to this species of "Landolphia/' wo may indeed say, "l}ï>qr quelque chose malheur est bon."

div.head: SUDAN TRADE
div.p: The following figures showing the approzimate increase of trade in the Nahud in the Kordofan Providence may be of interest. Previous to 1903, the returns are not sufficently accurate to be of value, though they were first commenced towards the end of 1901.

In the case of Budaa, i.e., cottons, suksuk, sugar &c., the values are those given on the passes. The values for ivory, feathers, &c. are Nuhud values given by merchants there, the wights are taken from the passes issued there. inc all cases, therefore, neither values nor weights are likely to be excessive.

The ivory comes from Dar Fertit* Dar Jangé, and small quantities from Darfur ; feathers from Dar Hmnar and Darfur ; Rhino from Dar Fertit ; tobacco all from Darfur, tho cattle from Dor Jangé and Darfur.

The decrease in cattle in 1904 is chiefly due to the b id prices at Omdurman. The above figures do not include cattle sent to Dar Jangé, •f which no record h is hitherto been kept rhis will lie done in 1905.

The merchants anticipate a large increase this year in ivory and some increase in feathers ind cattle, but there will be a largo decrease in tobacco due to tho partial if not complete failure of the now crop in Darfur this year.

div.head: EGYPT'S IMPORTS OF BUILDING MATERIAL
BY STANLEY DORLING.
div.p: Broadly reviewing this subject, one is, in spite of the relative insignificance of British imports, perhaps less ready than over to sympathise with the Home Manufacturer. Statistics for piat years show a singular scarcity of British imports in connection with the building trade. On the other hand, the increase in Continental importations is particularly conspicuous. If one listens to any exponent of Protectionist views, one hears, that with an opeu field, British trade holds its own. Egypt has no preferential tariff, yet in one item only in connection with this trado, namely sanitary goods, does Great Britain heather Continental neighbours. Steel joists, builders' ironmongery, Portland cement, tiles, (both roofing and flooring;, plumbing material, glass ; one could almost enumerate the builders' entire requirements, aud still not find a British production. The reason is not far to seek ; the stock of British manufactured builder's goods in this country is almost nil. Yet in many cases, more particularly in ironmongery, the ^British article, when obtained either direct from the makers, or through London buyers, is better and in many instances cheaper than its American or Continental equivalent. One would naturally assume that, if this be the case, British goods must hold their own or even surpass all competitors. This leads us to consider in whose hunds is the building trade in this country f Who are the consumers of building material ! On every hand one sees buildings in progress, but for one large structure in tho hands of a large firm, there are a dozen small buildings in the hands of small firms. We may, for the moment, grant that tho large contractor kuows where to get the best and cheapest goods ; every w. ek his London and Continental buyers inform him as to relative prices. But take the enormous number of small firms, several Italian, the majority native ; &s their requirements crop up, it is to the local vendor they raws* go. This brings us back to the qu istion of st »cks in the hands of the lo al vendors. Whatever his «tuck of goods may be, they certainly are not British. Once more then we are lod to the old recommendation go often quoted by this Chamber, to British manufacturers, namely, seud capable travellers, push the Briti-h article. In many branches of the trade, were this d >ne, a large amount of businass could be brought to Great Britain. But to go a step further, it eau un hesitatingly be stated that almost tho entire trade of builders' ironmonger)- could be captur
ed by tliahonie manufacturer, if bi st goods were suited to this market \

It does not lie within the scope of this short article to give details of requirements, they need careful study on the spot by technical inen. Sufficient to state that conditions are necessarily widely different from those at home The Marseilles productions,- roofing tileq h »'l *w bricks,' «üfcc., enjoy almost a mono i*o!y ii Egypt, suffering only <nme slight com- !*etition from Italy. The English iile or slate is never .«C30 here. Marseilles* tiles delivered on Wf.rks in Alexandria run £5 per thousand. Th ir larger size, however, gives great covering <sapaci:y, a square metre consisting of 16 tiles, which runs out at 15/3 per square (100 ft). It is possible British tile , makers may get down to this price. Moreover, with theft superior and lighter article as compared with the French production, the English tile would allow a roof of lighter scantling to be conducted. This would highly recommend them to architects in a country like Egypt, where timber is dear. English Portland cement is largely imported and used by builders, but a cheap quick-setting quality would always find a market. Flooring tiles are in great demand in E?yptv which is at present met bÿ local manufacturers, who supply a cheap pressed cement tile. The arficle is most inferior, bat it is made .to meet the requirements and sells widely. Rolled steel girders of British make are never seen here. On this subject itis impossible to say anything, but rdther to ask tho managers of British ^rolling mil!» why the British irirders should be 65 % dearer than their Belgian or German fellows of similar section. 'The old reply, of superior quMity counts for nothing, the Continental production is good enough, and consequently sells. Inclosing these few remarks one might perhaps draw'the ntteutio'i of English producers to the fact that of all trades probab'y none has shared in such a large degree the phenomeual prosperity of Egypt during tho last two years as has the building trade. But be that os it may, only those io the trade know how keen is competition, and how the necessity for purchasing the cheapest material is forced on the builders. Hence if home markets arc to supply. this trade, the urgency of producing cheap suitable material cannot be too clearly impressed on those desirous of making a bid for Egyptian business. It can safely be said, that Egypt having once started on her career of prosperity, her progress will not be stationary Each year will show her in the ascendant. Her extraordinary natural resources alone are a guarantee. Therefore a little time and money spent by English producers catering for builders' requirements here will, we feel sure, find an ample return in the future.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT
div.p: The "Statist" remarks:- W e understand tbs the National Bank of Kzypt will pay for th past year a dividend at the rate of 7 per per annum, against 6 per cent, lor the pre* »

; ing year. No official announcement to tl i effect has yet been made, for the meeting a. j not be held for .*>oine <Ly*. But we believe , j information to be quite correct. The hank i j admirably managed, aud, as our reader- kuq* Egypt ha» been making great progre-s. Uou sequently, the business of the hauk i? iucreai ing so steadily and rapidly, kthat not ouly is il able, as we have just said, to ]my a Light» dividend, but it hu- decided upon aliea issui of capital. The existing «• ipita! amounts U ^50,000 shares oi £10 each; aud we understart i that the new. issue will he 50 OOP shares, whici will raise the capital to 300,ooo share», o £3,000,000 nomioal. The issue price of th< new shares, we believe, will be £20. All tin shows the progress the bank is miking, and i no doubt encourage-» speculation. Egypt, as w have already said, has done won ierfully wel of late, and, in spite-of the fall iu the price t cotton, is doing well still. If there .is a g x> Nile there is no reasou to doubt that the ptu« parity will continue. Therefore there is a *p< culative spirit abroad, and it looks as if then were a good deal of speculation in the share of the National Bank of Egypt, for as we wnt they are at 27 £ and the other day they wer over 28. This seems an exaggerated price for security receiving? peroent, dividend. Nodouk the 8pecculators argue that buying now th$ will get "rights" and so ou, aud that bank is making so much progress that tti dividend will be mcrea-ied steadily in th future. We have not the {east intention t disparage the Bonk. We fiel sure, on th contrary, that its progress will be steady. A the same, we venture to think that 27£ is a extravagant price for an 8 per cent, share A we have already stated, the nominal capital c the Bank will be 300,000 shares when the im i<*ue is made. At 27£ the market estimate the value of these 300,000 «bares at the in meuse sum of 8} millions. What burines» mus the purchasers of the shares at present prit* expect the bank to do ? and what profits mut they anticipate it to make in order to be abl to pay a dividend that will justify such » price ?

div.head: UNDER THE MOSQUITO NET.
div.p: "As I laye a think yaye"
Ingoldsby.
In the Commonplace Book to which I referred ln^t week ^ found tin* following little fable*.— *
"A centipede was happy quite Until a toad in fuu Said "Pray which leg goes after which This worked her mind to such a pitch She lay distracted in a ditch
Considering how to run. '

The writer of these lines must have been thinking a little—perliapa agood deal—of some ol the things that we daily see in nature which human intelligence is utterly unable to account for and which the more we* think about the less we can understand. We may devote a lifetime to aualysiug and goiqç into the minutest details of any one brauch 6f science, and discover facts of the most vital importance to the wellbeing of the community, but when we come to the why and wherefore of it all, we get no .nearer than the centipede who doesn't know' "which leg goes after which."

And then we build elaborate theories and men and womep devote their lives to the study of various systems of philosophy. Volume after vullimo is written, and great reputation^ are made by writers of the most brilliant natural gifts and intellectual abilities. But the mystery of life remains unsolved, and all is summed up much in the same way as in the passage whicli concludes Herbert Spencer's àutvbiography, in which he refers to "—the insoluble questions concerning our owu fate : the evidence seeming so strong that the relations of mind and nervous structure are such that the cessatiou ot the one accompanies the dissolution of the other, while, simultaneously, comes the thought so strange, aud so diÛiuult to realise, that with death there lapses both the consciousness of existence aud the couscious- ness.of having existed.''

" Thus religious creeds, which in one way or another occupy the sphere that rational interpretation seeks to occupy and fails, and fails the more it seeks, 1 have come to regard with a sympathy bated on community of need : feeling that dissent from them results Irom ability to accept the solutions offered, joined with the wish that solutions could be louud."

Iu these words, written at the age of 73, when his life's work was ended and the great biologist felt that he was incapable of further mental effort, Herbert Spencer confessed his inability to solve the great questiou, not so much of future life as of the life around us, and there are inauy pas>ages in the works of Huxley, Darwin, and other great scientific authorities, that prove that they too recognise as fully as Spencer the impossibility of solving . the riddle.

Sir William Crooks aud Sir Oliver Lodge exteud their researches into occult phenomena, but whde getting perhaps a stage further in the direction of proving future existence and showing that "the mighty atom" is iudeed a tar mightier thing than was supposed, they and other investigators on these lines fail as completely as the rationalists in giving us any explanation ot the problem of life.

Meanwhile all this striving to attain to the impossible is continually furnishing us with fresh discoveries, and new facts are constantly being revealed iu nearly, if not quite, all department of science, that are extremely helpful to all who seek to improve the conditions uuder which life is lived. Sometimes one is disposed to wish that a halt could be called while practical application was given to the discoveries which have not as yet been made use of for the benefit of humanity.

The natious are too ready to use the newest discoveries in explosives, not to assist men to make Mother Earth give up her treasures so that hidden wealth may bo applied—as it should be—for the commou weal, but to make the engines of slaughter still more deadly tbai^ before, and to help to pile up the dead into ramparts behind which their comrades cau go on fighting.

Can anything more horrible be imagined than the tales of slaughter reaching us dail> from battle-fields, where hundreds of thousands . of men are doing their level best to kill each oth'er, in order to possess territory that belongs to neither ?

And what can show more clearly than these frightful examples of man's inhumanity to man how impossible it is to conceive the plan on which the government of this world is based! It is my firm conviction that withm certain limit* man has absolute free will, though how far these limita extend it is impossible to say. At all events they are probably sufficiently large to enable him to become the arbiter ot his own destiny.
And what is true of the individual may be equally true of the nation, so that we may ses
in a collective form the very same errors (and worse) thufcswe see in the person, exemplified in the conduct of the community at large, and with as woful results.

But as we reflect upon all.the things that make us *ad and perplexed, the thought that there i»au overruling Providence and a wise and just government of all things, is a very consoling one, aud os we Hud out from our own individual experiences, that much that we have been disposed to doubt in past times is indubitably truth, so we can derive comfort in the thought that whether events shape themselves as we would have them, or in apparently just the contrary direction, we can patiently await the day when we shall no louger see 'through & glass darkly.'

When one gets on to a subject of this sort there is'so much to say that I find it extremely difficult to condeuse into a limited space the thoughts that crowd upon me, and perhaps I have already said enough to give food for reflection for a good many hours to those who, like myself, like to ponder on some of the mysteries of life.

In a future paper, though not perhaps next week, I will tell of some of tho lessons I have learnt from a study—and much experience— of occultism and occult pheuomena. Much that comes under this term at present will probably soon bo recognised as practical and applied science, for the term "occult" simply means that the laws governing certain manifcotations are not yet understood. Magic only means wisdom.-(Magi—wise men). \
T. A.

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO RAILWAY.
div.p: According to the latest returns good progress is being made with the extension northward from the Victoria Falls of the Cape to Cairo Railway, and there is every reason to believe that railhead will be at Kalorno, the administrative centre of North-West lUiode*ia (Barutselaud), before next June. The further exteusiou of the liue for a distance of 250 miles beyou<4 Kalorno will be taken in hand by the Mashonaland Railway, which is working the line from Umtali, Salisbury, Buluwayo, and northward, and the terminus of the new extension at Broken Hill will be reached early next year. There will theu be continuous railway communication from Capetown to withiu a hundred miles of the south-east corner of the Congo Free State, a total dis tance of some 2,000 miles.

On the Victoria FallvKalomo section fifty miles of earthworks are fiuhhed, and at least twenty-five mile* of rail laid. For the purpo>*e* of the Kalomo-Brukeu Hill extension, and for other matters connected with the development of the country, the Mashonaland Railway in about to issue two and a-half million 5 per Cent. Debentures, which will be guaranteed by the British South Africa Company.

The terminus of the African Trans-Continental Telegraph is still at Ujiji, in German East Africa, on the eastern shore of Lake Tanganyika, jicuding discussion as to tlio possibility of employing a system of wireless telegraphy for some of the more difficult stretches of country to the north on the proposed route of tho telegraph line.

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL
div.p: At the meeting of the Associated Chambers of Commerce held in London last week, Sir Charles Palmer, of Newcastle, brought up the question of the management of the Sue/. Canal and the rates charged for trading steamers. He urged that the managing committee in London ought not to be a self-appointed one, and moved a resolution that the owners of all classes of British shipping 'making use of the canal should be adequately represented on the committee. He said that with the conclusion of the war in the Par East there would be a great development of trado with the East, and the canal would become a great factor to our commercial prosperity. He urged that the Board of Trado aud the Foreign Office should be asked to approach tho canal company with a view to their sending over representatives to confer with the English shipping community.— Col. Goffey, of Liverpool, secouded this, and it was agreed to.

div.head: EGYPT IN THE HOUSE
div.p: BRITISH TROOPS IN EGYPT.

In the House of Commons last week Mr. Weir asked the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, in view of £he fact that the. charges îûade on the Government of Egypt for the mainteuarce of British troops had recently been increased from L.E. 84,825 to LE. 97,000 (£100,000), whether the British force bad been in any way increased.

Earl Percy : The answer to the first paragraph is in . the negative. The contribution from the Egy ptian Exchequer has been fixed, by agreement between the two Government*, on tlie basis of the amount by which the cost of the garrison iu Egypt exceeds the cost of its maintenance at home. Its present strength is os follows : One battery Royal Field Artilr lery, one battery Mountain Artillery, one company Royal Engineers, three battalions infantry.
TREATMENT OF EGYPTIAN PILGRIMS AT 8UEZ.

On the 21st ulto. Mr. Weir asked the Undersecretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he was aware that the Khédivial Mail Steam Ship Company, which possess the monopoly of carrying Egyptian pilgrims, kept them waiting upwards of ten diays at Suez without food or shelter before allowing them to embark ; and would he consider the desirability of representing to tlie -Government of Egypt the expediency of communicating with the steamship company on the subject, with a view to prevent a similar cau*e for complaint in future pilgrimages !

Earl Percy If the hon. member will furnish me with full particulars, inquiry will be made, but matters of this kiud primarily concern the Egyptian authorities, and do not seem to call fur the intervention of his Majesty's Government.
SAFETY OF PILGRIMAGE.

Mr. Weir asked thi Uuder Secretary oi State for Foreign Affairs on the 22rd ult<\, * having re, a d to the fact that out of the 16,000 » pilgrims of Egyptian nationality who had j started on the pilgrimage of Mecca only 100 : had availed themselves of Government pro- ; tection by travelling with the Mahm&l, would he, iu view of the ill-treatment suffered by pilgrims last year when passing through Turkish Arabia, consider tho expediency of communicating with the Turkish Government in order • to secure some kind of protection for the pilgrims who are not accompanying tho Mahmal!

On the 21st ulto. Mr. Weir asked the Undersecretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he was aware that the Khédivial Mail Steam Ship Company, which possess the monopoly of carrying Egyptian pilgrims, kept them waiting upwards of ten diays at Suez without food or shelter before allowing them to embark ; and would he consider the desirability of representing to tlie -Government of Egypt the expediency of communicating with the steamship company on the subject, with a view to prevent a similar cau*e for complaint in future pilgrimages !

Earl Percy If the hon. member will furnish me with full particulars, inquiry will be made, but matters of this kiud primarily concern the Egyptian authorities, and do not seem to call fur the intervention of his Majesty's Government.
SAFETY OF PILGRIMAGE.

Mr. Weir asked thi Uuder Secretary oi State for Foreign Affairs on the 22rd ult<\, * having re, a d to the fact that out of the 16,000 » pilgrims of Egyptian nationality who had j started on the pilgrimage of Mecca only 100 : had availed themselves of Government pro- ; tection by travelling with the Mahm&l, would he, iu view of the ill-treatment suffered by pilgrims last year when passing through Turkish Arabia, consider tho expediency of communicating with the Turkish Government in order • to secure some kind of protection for the pilgrims who are not accompanying tho Mahmal! '

Earl Percy : As I informed the bon. member yesterday, matters of this kind primarily concern the Egyptian Government. Representations ha /c been made to the Turkish Government, and it is hoped that there may be no further cause for complaint.
INFANT MORTALITY IN EGYPT.

On the 23rd ult, Mr. Weir aked the Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he was aware that in Egypt one-third ojrthe- - children of the native population die within twelve mouths of birth, and that another third die lwlore they reach five years of age ; and ; — would lie consider the expediency of suggesting to the Government of Egypt that some inquiry should be made with a view to arrest this heavy infant mortality.
Earl Percy : Yes, Sir.

div.head: THE MECCA PILGRIMAGE
div.p: A graphic, vivacious, accurate, and entertaining account of a pilgrimage to Mecca by Hadji Khan in 1902 has lately been pu blished. Several travellers have already given us descriptions of this Mohamedan function, as well as of the Ka'bab, the sacred shrine of Mecca, but Hiulji Khan, being by birth an Islamite, had more opportunity of observing his co-religionists than men of other denominations who go tho re disguised, and require to be ou their guard to escape detection, while his avowed aguostioism in the matter of belief prevented superstition blindiug his eyes. What he saW' aud what he heard make one of the most enlightening and captivating books about the East ever written. He does not think much of the highly-paid clergy who have charge of the Ka'bah, for they Are allowing the place to fall into ruin, while they pocket the revenues that ought to be used for its repair; but ho pays just tribute to the enthusiasm of the rank and file of Islamism.While he was passing through the sacred shrine this feeling got the better even of his own agnosticism, and the song, 'Labbaik Allahomma Labbaik," describing the oneness of the Almighty, coming from thousands of throats, brought a feeling of awe upon him, and compelled him instinctively to join in its chorus, while, as he says, he rubbed his nose on the floor. Tho fountain of Zem zem is described as "neither sweet nor bitter, neither fresh nor salt, neither scented nor stinking, but appears to be a mixture of all these qualities, from which it would seem that it would make the fortune of any syndicate* of speculators who could get hold of the place to exploit as a chalybeate spriug. Slavery still exists in Arabia, and it is interesting to learn that a woman, if she be young, and "good to behold," costs from £20 to £50, while a man can be got at prices ranging from £15 up to £40.

div.head: Neglected Colds cause Consumption.
THE WHITE SCOURGE
div.p: MRS. ADDIE HARDING. MRS. MARY MEYER. MRS. FRANCES WILSON.
PROBABLY every case of consumption begins with a cold.
Consumption is generally classed as a hereditary disease, but consumption is not hereditary.
A constitutional weakness is inherited which renders one liable to consumption.
Even people who have strong lungs may acquire consumption from a cold.
Mrs. Addie Harding, 121 W, Brighton Ave., Syracuse, N. Y., writes:
"I have been a user of Peruna for the last twelve years and can truthfully say that there is no better medicine on earth.
"A SURE PREVENTATIVE."
"With me it is a sure preventative for colds and many other ills. In my home can always be found a bottle of Peruna. Two or three times a year I am troubled with my throat.
"I always had to have the services of my physician two or three times in each case.
"Although a user of Peruna, I never thought of taking it for my throat until about two years ago.
"I tried Peruna to check it, and to my great delight I was not troubled with the smothered and choked feeling and never have since.
"I can check it every time with Peruna.
"I certainly would not be without Peruna one minute."
Mrs. Mary Meyer, Thomson avenue, near Shell Road, Winfield, L. L, N. Y., writes:
"I have been annoyed with a cough for years.
"Often it was so bad that I could not sleep half the night. Many people thought I had consumption.
CONSUMPTION WAS FEARED.
"A woman recommended Peruna to me two years ago. I began to take Peruna and now I am perfectly free from a cough,
"I am glad to say that Peruna cured me entirely, I take Peruna occasionally when I do not feel well and I also give it to my children.
"Peruna is the best medicine for coughs and colds. I have told many people how much Peruna has helped me."
A neglected cold is a well-worn path to consumption.
Many a person catches cold and pays no attention to it.
He scarcely recovers from the first cold when he takes the second.
Still he gives it no heed, and possibly takes another cold, and so on.
He doses himself with bromides, quinine and various expectorants.
His case is catarrh, at this stage, and his case should be treated as catarrh.
A common cold is acute catarrh.
Finally, if the cold is allowed to continue, it becomes chronic catarrh.
Mrs, Frances Wilson, 82 Nelson street, Clinton, Mass., writes:
"Had you seen me at the time of my illness and now, you would not wonder that 1 take delight in sounding the praises of Peruna.
"My ailment was a severe cold which attacked the bronchial tubes and lungs.
"I followed your special directions and after using six bottles of Peruna I was on my feet again.
"I think Peruna a wonderful medicine."
All colds, coughs, bronchitis, laryngtis and tonsilitis should be treated as catarrh, as they are in reality catarrh.
The success of Peruna in relieving these cases entirely depends upon the fact that Peruna is a catarrh remedy.
It relieves catarrh wherever located in the system. Whether in the throat, bronchial tubes or lungs.
CONSUMPTION PREVENTED.
It has saved a multitude of peo-ple from consumption by eradicating catarrh before it reaches the lungs.
The tendency of catarrh of the throat or head is to spread downward to the lungs.
If taken in time, Peruna will prevent these cases.

We have in our files many testimonials from people who thought they were victims of consumption, but have been permanently relieved by the faithful use of Peruna. thus showing that catarrh was really the cause of their ailments.

For special directions everyone should read " The Ills of Life." a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings.

Des lots déjà sont loués de 3 à 5 £ le fed., ce qui représente déjà le 7 % des déboure. La Société a acheté *4,875 fed. de la Daïra Sanieh. div.head: Le Fort Kait Bey
et
La Tour des Romains
div.p: NouS recevons à ce sujet la lettre suivante : Monsieur le Directeur
de XEgyptian Gazette
Permettezmoi d'accouipagner de quelques observations l'entrefilet paru dans votre estimable Journal en date du 6 courant et signé Del toner.

Il faut avant tout coustiter, pour l'honneur de la vérité, que le jour même (15 Mai 1901,) où grâce à l'amabilité de M. le Professeur Schweinfurth, le fait que l'on est en train de procéder à des démolitions dans le fort Kait bey de votre ville, a été porté à la connaissance du Comité, celui-ci par la voix de son Président a demandé au Ministère de la Querre de faire surseoir à la démolition. Ce qui fut fait Ensuite un accord est intervenu entre les doux Administrations pour les travaux à exécuter, bien entendu, en excluant du programme tout travail de démolition.

Il était certes très regrettable de voir tomber sous la pioche des démolisseurs le fort Kait bey qui est le. seul complet et de valeur historique it Alexandrie, et le Comité n'a pas moins regretté de n'avoir pu iutervenir eu sa faveur que lorsque la silhouette si pittoresque do ce fort a été terriblement endommagée.
Sur co poiut nous partageons les regrets exprimés par Mi Deltaner, le signataire de l'article, mais nous sommes loin d'être de sou avis en ce qui concerne la Tour dite des Romains.
Nous ne comprenons pas pouVquoi en défendant si chaleureusement le fort Kait bey, ou peut montrer tant d'iudiffércuce, pour ne pas dire autro chose, à l'égard de la Tour de Missal lah.

Cette tour qui est bien une œuvre de l'art arabe et qui représente le dernier vestige des travaux do fortification de la ville d'Alexandrie du coté de la mer, mérite l'iotérêt du public et toute la protection du Comité. Aussi n'a-t-il jamais été question de la reconstruire mais tout bounemeut de la consolider par une simple maçonnerie afin de la conserver à l'état oh elle se trouve.

Si cette tour se trouvait au Caire, qui est beaucoup plu» riche qu'Alexaudrie eu monuments arabes, on n'aurait jamais songé à sa démolition. D'ailleurs d'après une entente intervenue entre le Comité et Tex-Administrateur de la Municipalité d'Alexandrie, la Tour de Miasallah se trouvera un jour placée dans l'un des angles d'un square que l'on doit prochainement créer dans son voisinage, et nous sommes sûre que ce point de la ville ne fera qu'y gagner.

Le sort de cette modeste tour est celui de bien d'autres monumonts de tous pays, où après s'être acharné à vouloir les démolir, on finit par les laisser subsister et par la suite on est très heureux de les avoir cou -ervés.
Espérons que ce sera encore là le cas de la Tour de Missallah dite des Romains.
Z.
Le Caire, le 9 mars 1905.

div.head: La Conference Judiciaire
div.p: La réunion de la conférence judiciaire inter hationale aura lieu mercredi prochain au mi histère des affaires étrangères. A cette séance los ministres plénipotentiaires prendront ofii ciellement connaissance des propositions de la Commission technique qui doivent faire l'obje de la discussion.

On ne sait pas encore si une seule séance suffira pour épuiser l'ordre du jour. Les Minis très transmettront ensuite les résolutions défi nitivea de la conférence aux puissances dont il- sont les mandataires et auxquelles il appar tient de prendre une décision définitive. Ce n'est qu'après l'approbation des puissances que sera rendu le décret khédivial promulgant le réformes qui auront été adoptées.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Wakfs privés de S.A. lo Khédive mot en adjudication les deux entreprises des travaux nécessaires aux façades Est et Ouest de la mosquée d'El-Rifaï.
La présentation des offres aura lieu jusqu'au lundi 'JO mars 1905 à 10 heures du matin.

Tous ceux qui désireront concourir à cette adjudication pourront prendre connaissance des plans, dessins et cahiers des charges à l'administration des Wakfs au Palais d'Abdine ou au bureau situé à la maison No. 35, rue El- Maghrabi vis-à vis de la bourse, tous les jours de 3 b. à 5 h. de l'àprès-midi excepté les vendredis et les jours de fête.
Les offres, qui devront être faites pour chaque façade séparément, seront adressées sous pli cacheté au Directeur des Wakfs Khédiviaux privés et porteront le nom de l'entrepreneur.
Les concurrents devrout se présenter à i'ad- miuistr&tion à la date fixée munis des garanties nécessaires.

lies offres faites après le délai sus-mentionné ou qui ne seront pas accompagnées des garanties ne seront pas admises, il en est de même des offres présentées sous un nom collectif ou colui d'une société.
L'administration se réserve le droit d'accepter ou de refuser nute offre sans en donner les motifs.
Les garanties pour les travaux sus-mentionnés sont les suivautes : 230 L.E. pour démolition, reconstruction et travaux d'embellissement de la façade Est.
350 LE. pour démolition et e^calior en marbre de la façade Ouest 25565-3-1

Messieurs les actionnaires sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire, aux termes de l'article 30 des Statuts pour le Lundi 10 Avril 1905, à 4 heures de relevée, au Siège Social au Caire.
Tout actionnaire propriétaire de 20 actions au moins qui voudra prendre part à la réunion devra faire le dépôt do ses actions avant le 6 Avril 1905.
